content: Afghans step up effort to destroy opium fields Some GIs skeptical of eradication plan, say alternatives should be provided Afghanistan produces more than 90 percent of the world’s opium, the base ingredient for heroin. The United Nations estimates the drug is worth $3 billion a year to the Afghan economy. The Taliban is believed to skim at least $100 million off the trade, most by taxing production and transport. Full article at > >http://www.stripes.com/article.asp?section=104&article=61958 No question this needs to be done but how will they do it and what will be the end result? It has to be prelaced with something for the farmers.

From what I've read, it is illegal to grow opium poppy in the United States - correct me if I'm wrong. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opium#Legal_production 80% is still imported from India and Turkey. Please see the case study for Turkey from the Poppy For Medicine link: "...The Turkish political dynamic was such that poppy farmers’ interests were key to the stability of the country. When Turkey deemed total eradication both technically and socially impracticable, the US and the Turkish Governments worked together to implement a poppy licensing system for the production of opium-based medicines, as an alternative means of bringing poppy cultivation under control." That "none of what is grown in Afghanistan is used for medical stuff", is exactly the problem - and starting to use it for medicine would be a solution.
